item.description:
Meetings

Weekly Meeting: Revamping The Group (12/03/2022)

Links

  • Audio
  • Slides

Objectives

  • Revamping the group, re-launching totally new activities and approach.

Summary

  • Launching new activities which require minimal time, technical background, and commitment. We are going to begin with those, Then slowly endorse more collaborative activities. That, In order for everything to be clear.

Quotes

  • mostafa: I had two big false assumptions about this group, time and background.

Weekly Meeting: More Courses (26/02/2022)

Links

  • Audio
  • Slides

Objective

  • Address the challenges the group is facing.
  • Suggest more elementary courses to pursued, and how to use the three of them simultaneously.

Quotes

  • protechthor: I do really appreciate that we can pick-up more courses.

Weekly Meeting (19/02/2022)

Links

  • Audio

Objectives

  • Follow-up what members have achieved of Erik’s course, and discuss their solved assignments.

Summary

  • Everyone expressed struggling with the course, and nearly all members couldn’t solve the exercises.

Quotes

  • mostafa: I am encouraged by everyone’s willingness to express her/his struggle, and to persistently learn from mistakes and improve.

Weekly Meeting (12/02/2022)

Links

  • Audio

Objectives

  • Technical discussion, Lectures and Assignment 1.
  • Casual discussion, whether the course was too difficult.
  • Casual discussion, Generally related to the course.
  • Social, Meeting new members.

Summary

  • ben introduces himself: graduated from math major, transitioned to software industry and has been working for 2 years. intersted now in theoretical computer science.
  • caio introduces himself: fresh CS alumni; currently pursuing a master in compilers; motivated to study algorithms for code optimization.
  • lucper and caio are friends and had an internships together.
  • most members did not solve assignment 1 but they are planning for it the next week end.
  • for most members, this course is the first time they see proofs within the context of algorithms.
  • ben initiates a discussion, simple algorithm but tricky proof
    • mostafa addressed understanding a solution, and being able to creatively come up with a new, are totally two different skills.
    • lucper addresses that happens very commonly in combinatorics, A problem easily understood but very trikcy to solve it.
  • ben asks whether it is a pattern for greedy algorithms to be solved by induction
    • mostafa answers when an algorithm is formulated recursively or in terms of smaller instances of the same problem, Then induction is a very likely approach.
    • caio agrees what mostafa as he had a similar advice from his professor.
    • lucper pointes to algorithm design book by Kleinberg and Tardos for an alternative proof by contradiction
  • mostafa initaties a discussion, school systems are not the best environment for training on creatively coming up with novel ideas.
  • mostafa initaites a discussion, thinking of simpler problems or different versions as a problem solving strategy.
    • ben expresses this is his main strategy.
    • caio mentions a quote from how to prove it by George Polya.
    • lucper agrees.
  • mostafa ends up the with posing a question: If progressing slowly by thinking of related problems is our sole approach for progress, Is it possible to achieve breakthroughs or unexpected leaps?

Quotes

  • caio: if you cannot solve a problem, try to think of an easier version for it.

First Meeting (05/02/2022)

Links

  • Audio

Objectives

  • Networking, Where Members introduce themselves (15 min)
  • Discussion, On students' collaboration and online communities; Their challenges and suggested solutions (20 min)
  • Discussion, On members' skills and goals, and how to leverage that for Projects and subsidy learning (10 min)
  • Gaming, Multiplayer among members (5 min)

Summary

  • members introduce themselves

    • lucas: Brazil; Master student in computational biology; Had an unfinished grad course in algorithms; Aims for advanced topics in algorithms.
    • protechthor: Cameron; Math+CS Undergrad; Aims for competitive programming and technical interviews.
    • salvaCasta: Argentina; Undergrad special degree of Engineering and CS with equivalent to a master. took a first course in algorithms. wishes to prepare for hard courses. self-studies measure theory. likes information theory and prepares for it by analysis
    • tilde: Sweden; Undergrad special degree of CS and Engineering equivalent to a Master; Interested in Machine Learning; Has solid background in Algorithms and Data structures. Aims for proofs lens of algorithms; Collaborated with mechatronics and political sciences students
    • ashok: Fresh highschool alumni; Familiar with programming and done machine learning projects; Lacks advanced math and foundational algorithms.

  • mostafa pointed to curious intersections between computer science and information/communication.

  • protechthor expressed struggling with measure theory, as there’s no clear motivation for it; it is too way abstract. mostafa offered help through mathematical logic for appreciating rigorous approaches.

  • mostafa addressed that members might consider practical programming side of algorithms, besides course’s main goal of proofs.

  • ashok explained how Physics might contribute to computing, as processing power is physically realized through the laws of physics.

  • Members talked about the first picture of a blackhole (see this)

Quotes

  • salvaCasta: I love it, definitely love it. i do not study math at university. so I just buy a book and try to do every exercise.
  • salvaCasta: Some proofs are just very hard to come up with, but not in technical terms, but rather in creative terms.
  • mostafa: I am sure you will learn alot from this community, ashok .. let me stress the benefit is mutual. I am going to learn from ashok.
  • mostafa: Eventhough ashok is a fresh high school alumini, He was able to actively participate in our discussion.
  • tilde: A course where most of the students participated in the meeting. The teacher created an environment where you felt comfortable to ask questions, even if they felt stupid. He never disregarded those questions. He also started every lecture with a very basic down to earth explanation.

Intro (20/01/2022)

Links

  • Video
  • Slides

Objectives

  • Communicate group’s pedagogy, Including motivation, goals, and activities.
